title: When males are not needed
intro: Many animals can reproduce without having sex. Does it bring any advantage to the species that do that? Neil and Rob talk about science, listen to an evolutionary biologist and teach you vocabulary along the way.
this_week_question: In Britain’s Chester Zoo in 2006, ‘Flora’ laid eleven eggs that developed into healthy babies. Her zookeepers were mystified because Flora had only been kept with other females and had never been near a male. But what type of animal was Flora?
Listen to the programme to find out the answer.

vocab.desc: situation which seems contradictory or impossible because it contains two opposite facts
when an egg breaks open in order to allow the young animal to come out
situation where you can enjoy the advantages of very different things at the same time
hedge your bets follow two courses of action instead of making a decision between them in order to avoid the possibility of losing out

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Neil.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: And I’m Rob.Do you think there are big differences between men and women, Neil?  – Apart from the old stereotypes we sometimes hear, like - that men can’t express emotions…

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I suppose biologically there are differences, Rob. I mean, men and women’s bodies are different.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Right, and it takes both - a man and a woman - to make a baby.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, that’s true - in humans anyway. But in this programme we’ll be hearing about creatures in the wild where the classic ‘boy meets girl’ love story doesn’t apply.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Yes, we’ll be meeting some female animals who don’t need a male to make babies.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: These creatures reproduce by parthenogenesis - also called ‘virgin birth’, this is the process where the female can reproduce without a mate – the term used for an animal’s sexual partner.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: All animal species survive by making babies – reproducing to make copies of themselves. But amazingly, the female of some species can do it all by herself!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: But before that, it’s time for my quiz question. In Britain’s Chester Zoo in 2006, ‘Flora’ laid eleven eggs that developed into healthy babies. Her zookeepers were mystified because Flora had only been kept with other females and had never been near a male. But what type of animal was Flora? Was she: a) a python?, b) a zebra shark?,  or c) a Komodo dragon?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Hmm, pythons are pretty unusual creatures so I’ll say Flora was a python.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: OK, Rob, we’ll find out later if you’re right. Actually, it’s not only reptiles who behave this way – the females of many animal species are able to reproduce without sex.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: By doing this they gain several advantages: they can rapidly spread, colonise and control large areas and they don’t waste time and energy looking for a mate.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: But if a world without sex is so much better, why bother with males at all?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Good question, Neil, and one which BBC World Service programme, Discovery, asked evolutionary biologist, Chris Wilson:

transcript.author: Chris Wilson
transcript.text: Well absolutely! And there are other advantages I mean, if you’re an all-female population you don’t have to waste time searching and competing for mates , there are no more sexually-transmitted diseases and so it seems like the easiest decision – and yet, less than one percent of all animal species are completely celibate – and that’s a huge fundamental puzzle in evolutionary biology that we’re still not entirely sure we understand – it’s called sometimes the paradox of sex.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Despite the advantages of going without sex, in reality fewer than one percent of all animals are celibate – live without having sex.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: This begs the question, why is sex so common when it seems so inefficient? Chris calls this the paradox of sex. A paradox is a situation which seems contradictory because it contains two opposite facts, for example, the existence of males if we can reproduce without them.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: As a male myself, I have to say I’m feeling a little underappreciated right now, Rob!

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Well don’t worry, Neil, because it turns out there might be a use for males after all! It seems the sex paradox has been solved by one of nature’s most ingenious insects - aphids.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Here’s ecologist, Amber Wright, explaining how to the BBC World Service’s Discovery programme.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: See if you can hear the strategy American aphids use to reproduce.

transcript.author: Amber Wright
transcript.text: The aphids we have in the US – when spring comes around, the eggs hatch and they’ll be all female for several generations, and then at the end of the summer they will hatch out males and females and mate, and then create eggs that wait for next year – kind of the best of both worlds.

transcript.author: Presenter Lucy Cooke
transcript.text: Hedging their bets basically – using cloning to rapidly colonise and then using sex to mix up the genes.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: In the spring, female aphids lay eggs which hatch – break open allowing the young to come out. The young aphids that hatch are all female.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: But later, at the end of summer, both female and male aphids hatch out and start to reproduce by mating. So the aphids have the best of best of both worlds – they enjoy the advantages of very different things at the same time.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Or to put it another way, the aphids hedge their bets – they follow two courses of action instead of choosing between them. By cloning themselves with ‘virgin births’ and reproducing sexually, aphids maximise their chances of survival.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Gardeners around the world will be upset to hear that – those young aphids just love eating tomato plants!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: But on the plus side, it seems being male can be useful after all.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: But not if you’re Flora, the female you asked about in your quiz question. So, what type of animal was she?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Right – I asked whether the-virgin-Flora was a) a python, b) a shark or c) a Komodo dragon.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: I guessed a) a python.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, Rob, you’re right that some female pythons can reproduce by themselves – and sharks too – but the correct answer is that Flora was, c) a Komodo dragon.

transcript.author: mate
transcript.text: OK, let’s recap the vocabulary, starting with  - an animal’s sexual partner; something you don’t have if you’re celibate – living without sex.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Animal eggs hatch – or break open to let the young out.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And a paradox is a situation which seems contradictory because it contains two opposite facts.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Species which reproduce parthenogenetically and sexually have the best of both worlds - enjoy the advantages of very different things at the same time.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And if you hedge your bets , you follow two courses of action instead of choosing between them so you don’t miss out.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Well, that’s all there’s time for. Bye for now!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Goodbye!
